title: Security
content:
I am using Firefox version 112.02 with Windows 10 and am being told by some websites that my browser is out-of-date and that I cannot continue. Then today I was purchasing tickets for a show and the checkout was blocked by another message which said "Firefox Can’t Open This Page. To protect your security, **********.co.uk will not allow Firefox to display the page if another site has embedded it. To see this page, you need to open it in a new window."

Please advise how these measures can be removed or disabled as they are a perfect nuisance.

Simon Bucknall
creator: SiriusB

title: Have a Sync problem (starwebsearch.com)
content:
Hi

Every time I sync my Firefox with my Firefox account, it syncs a Tab that opens every time I run Firefox (starwebsearch.com) the tab link is this http://ww38.starwebsearch.com/index.php?from=3&subid1=20230426-2018-245b-9244-563e7a62d228

No matter I reinstall Firefox or redo my computer, if I sync my Firefox this will return every time I open my Firefox... But if I don't sync my Firefox, this won't appear ever, of if I unsync it, it will stop.

How do I remove this malicious tab from my Firefox account? This is very very very annoying

Thanks in advance
creator: prinnythedood

title: Wikipedia and Fandom page previews appear to be entirely broken on Firefox specifically
content:
Hi. I'm experiencing a minor but very noticeable issue with Wikipedia's (and to a lesser extent, Fandom)'s page preview functionality. For those of you who don't know the exact terminology, Wikipedia loads previews of hovered links when on desktop- it's extremely useful to prevent needing to load a separate tab when you can vaguely guess or get a grasp of the basics from just a single look at the starting paragraph. On Fandom wikis (which are extremely varied), it can also be helpful just to understand a single item in a game which has its own wiki page, or otherwise see otherwise webpage-bloating information without blowing up the amount of windows you have open.

Currently, neither are working on Firefox. I checked with Edge, and Wikipedia's previews work as intended. Hovering Wikipedia's internal links in Firefox results in the normal tooltip appearing (a small bar showing the title of the page being hovered). I have tried:

  • Checking the network page. There is no network request for a page showing when the link is hovered in Firefox, but there is a network request in Edge.
  • Messing with a few config settings in Firefox. None functioned well, though I'm sure I don't know every single one (I'm not very well-learned in regards to that.)
  • Clearing the cache, cookies, and more on Wikipedia. No changes.
  • Changing Wikipedia's internal Page Preview settings. No differences- though I did note there was no "enable Page Preview" link at the bottom of the page, which should have been there as per Wikipedia's own documentation.
  • Started Firefox multiple times in troubleshooting mode. It's not an extension issue, and behaviour did not change.
  • Manually turned off adblocking extensions. Nope.
  • Attempted to make the ?debug=true portion of Wikipedia work. No javascript errors returned in the console, but there was also no javascript section to filter through so I'm not sure if I did it correctly.

I'm fairly certain this is a personal issue with my version of Firefox rather than a Wikipedia issue. If it was a Wikipedia issue, then it would definitely have more than around three results on a Google search. I also know as of a month or so ago that it worked on my other computer; this computer appears to have a fairly-well reported GPU memory leak in reference to Firefox, so I assume something there is going wrong. (The GPU memory leak should be fine. A restart and cleared memory on RAMMap fixes things up for the short term.)

Thanks!
creator: josh22756

title: Podivné zobrazení webu Strava.com

title: Exceptions to Enhanced Tracking Prevention do not work
content:
I'm on a website, https://a.com, which attempts to load an image from https://b.com. For some reason this gets blocked by Enhanced Tracking Prevention, but no worries I assume, I'll just add an exception in the settings.

Only adding an exception does absolutely nothing. Despite adding an exception for it, any request to https://b.com is still blocked by Firefox automatically, leaving me only with the option to disable tracking prevention for https://a.com entirely, or not get any images to load.

How exactly are exceptions supposed to work if not like this?
creator: thunfremlinc

title: google maps
content: When I use Firefox to open google maps, it shows my location at least 30 kms from my actual location, which means all the local information is wrong and I have to scroll and reset. I am sure it didn't use to be like this. I have tried everything I can think of or find to tell Google maps that I am in Ellesmere Port not Bebington but to no avail. Given that these days I would think computer information could almost tell me what room of the house my PC was in I am baffled why it can't even get the right town. What's going on?
